test

Class InteractiveConsoleTest

  • java.lang.Object
    • test.InteractiveConsoleTest
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    BookDatabaseSubTest, BookSearchTest, BooksInteractiveConsoleTest, CitiesInteracitveConsoleTest, RecommendationSubtest

    public abstract class InteractiveConsoleTest
extends java.lang.Object
    Contains some useful methods for testing with the interactive console. Extend this class to write interactive console tests.

    The different test methods

    There are different methods that can be used for testing. However, there are two big differences:
    • noOutputTest, errorTest, oneLineTest and multiLineTest are fine for most cases, but lack functionality when it comes to more complex test scenarios.
    • sessionTest provides an API that lets one accurately specify what commands should lead to which output. Plus, it is expandable by implementing new Runs. It covers all functionality covered by the other methods and adds very little clutter compared to the other ones.

    Asserting the system exit status

    Using TestObject.allowSystemExit(SystemExitStatus)
    Preferably by overriding defaultSystemExitStatus(). This was the old way, but is now Deprecated.
    The new way
    The new way of asserting the system exit status has two big advantages:
    • Error messages are shown for failed tests if more than the exit status was wrong
    • It differentiates between an expected and an allowed system exit status.
    To use the new way, call setAllowedSystemExitStatus(SystemExitStatus) or setExpectedSystemStatus(SystemExitStatus) before running one of the test methods. Typically, a test class does this once in its constructor.
    Since:
    05.01.2015
    Version:
    1.3
    Author:
    Roman Langrehr, Joshua Gleitze

    • Field Detail

      • globalTimeout

        public final org.junit.rules.Timeout globalTimeout
        A test is terminated after a certain timeout (default: 5s). This assures that a test fails if the tested class fails to terminate. Some users may mistake a non terminating test as being successful. Override getDefaultTimeoutMs() to change the value for your test, don't touch this property!

      • defaultSystemExitStatus

        @Deprecated
public void defaultSystemExitStatus()
        Deprecated. 
        Gets called before each test run. Sets the allowed system exit status to SystemExitStatus.WITH_0. Override this method if you wish to have another default system exit status.

        Deprecated. Please use setAllowedSystemExitStatus(SystemExitStatus) and setExpectedSystemStatus(SystemExitStatus).

      • checkSystemExitStatus

        protected final void checkSystemExitStatus(java.lang.String[] commands,
                         java.lang.String[] args0)
        Checks the exit status of a tested method. Has to be called after call to a TestObject run method.
        Parameters:
        commands - The commands that were run on the interactive console.
        args0 - The arguments the main method was called with in the test run.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - If initSystemExitStatusCheck() has not been called before the test run.

      • consoleMessage

        protected java.lang.String consoleMessage(java.lang.String[] commands,

        The message that should be printed at the start of an error message. Override this method to print your own message.
        Parameters:
        commands - the commands that were run on the interactive console
        commandLineArguments - the command line arguments the console was called with
        Returns:
        a String representing the session

      • errorTest

        protected void errorTest(java.lang.String command,
             java.lang.String... args0)
        Tests an interactive console program with one command that should output an error message. Calls the main method with optional args0 on the test object and runs the command on it. Asserts that the tested class called Terminal.printLine at least once and the output starts with "Error,".
        NOTE: This method does not allow to call System.exit(1). If you expect the implemented class to do so, call TestObject.allowSystemExit(SystemExitStatus.WITH_GREATER_THAN_0); before.
        Parameters:
        command - The command to run on the console.
        args0 - The arguments for the main-method

      • errorTest

        protected void errorTest(java.lang.String[] commands,
             java.lang.String... args0)
        Tests an interactive console program with multiple commands that should output an error message. Calls the main method with optional args0 on the test object and runs all commands on it. Asserts that the tested class called Terminal.printLine at least once and the output starts with "Error,".
        NOTE: This method does not allow to call System.exit(1). If you expect the implemented class to do so, call TestObject.allowSystemExit(SystemExitStatus.WITH_GREATER_THAN_0); before.
        Parameters:
        commands - The commands to run on the console
        args0 - The arguments for the main-method

      • getArguments

        protected java.lang.String getArguments(java.lang.String[] commandLineArguments)
        A representation of command line arguments. Returns that has been called with the command line arguments, concatenated with a list representation of commandLineArguments. Returns an empty String if commandLineArguments is null or empty.
        Parameters:
        commandLineArguments - the cli arguments to process
        Returns:
        a String represention commandLineArguments

      • getMatchers

        @SafeVarargs
protected final java.util.List<org.hamcrest.Matcher<java.lang.String>> getMatchers(org.hamcrest.Matcher<java.lang.String>... matchers)
        Constructs a List of matchers to be used for the multiLineTest(java.lang.String, java.util.List<org.hamcrest.Matcher<java.lang.String>>, java.lang.String...) methods. This method can be used to write down expected output nicely, one Matcher per line. For example: 
         
        // @formatter:off
        expectedResultMatchers = getMatchers(
                is("Hintertupfingen:3"),
                startsWith("Error,"),
                is("Hintertupfingen:3")
        );
        // @formatter:on
        Parameters:
        matchers - the matchers to construct the list.
        Returns:
        a list containing matchers

      • initSystemExitStatusCheck

        protected final void initSystemExitStatusCheck()
        Initiates the new way of system exit status checking. Has to be called before the first call to a TestObject run method.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - If this method has already been called without a subsequent call to checkSystemExitStatus(String[], String[]).

      • multiLineTest

        protected void multiLineTest(java.lang.String command,
                 java.util.List<org.hamcrest.Matcher<java.lang.String>> expectedResults,
                 java.lang.String... args0)
        Tests an interactive console program with one command that output multiple lines. Calls the main method with optional args0 on the test object and runs all commands on it. Asserts that each output line matches the expectedResults. Make sure to provide exactly one Matcher for each output line you expect.

        Example:
        Say we expect the main method to output three times "Success!" and then a line starting with "Error,". The call would work like this: 
         
 List<Matcher<String>> expectedResults = new Vector<Matcher<String>>();
 expectedResults.add(is("Success!"));
 expectedResults.add(is("Success!"));
 expectedResults.add(is("Success!"));
 expectedResults.add(startsWith("Success!"));
 multiLineTest(commands, expectedResults, args0);
        Parameters:
        command - The command to run on the console.
        expectedResults - Matchers for every expected output line. Each line of the output will be asserted to match the corresponding Matcher.
        args0 - The arguments for the main-method

      • multiLineTest

        protected void multiLineTest(java.lang.String command,
                 java.lang.String[] expectedResults,
                 java.lang.String... args0)
        Tests an interactive console program with one command that should output multiple lines. Calls the main method with optional args0 on the test object and runs all commands on it. Asserts that each output line matches the expectedResults. Make sure to provide exactly one Matcher for each output line you expect.
        Parameters:
        command - The command to run on the console.
        expectedResults - Strings for every expected output line. Each line of the output will be asserted to be equal to the corresponding String in expectedResults.
        args0 - The arguments for the main-method

      • multiLineTest

        protected void multiLineTest(java.lang.String[] commands,
                 java.util.List<org.hamcrest.Matcher<java.lang.String>> expectedResults,
                 java.lang.String... args0)
        Tests an interactive console program with multiple commands that should output multiple lines. Calls the main method with optional args0 on the test object and runs all commands on it. Asserts that each output line matches the expectedResults. Make sure to provide exactly one Matcher for each output line you expect.

        Example:
        Say we expect the main method to output three times "Success!", an empty line afterwards, and then a line starting with "Error,". The call would work like this: 
         
 List<Matcher<String>> expectedResults = new Vector<Matcher<String>>();
 expectedResults.add(is("Success!"));
 expectedResults.add(is("Success!"));
 expectedResults.add(is("Success!"));
 expectedResults.add(startsWith("Success!"));
 multiLineTest(commands, expectedResults, args0);
        Parameters:
        commands - The commands to run on the console.
        expectedResults - Matchers for every expected output line. Each line of the output will be asserted to match the corresponding Matcher in expectedResults.
        args0 - The arguments for the main-method

        protected void noOutputTest(java.lang.String command,
                java.lang.String... args0)
        Tests an interactive console program with one command that should not output anything. Calls the main method with optional args0 on the test object and runs command on it. Asserts that the tested class never called Terminal.printLine.
        Parameters:
        command - The command to run on the test object.
        args0 - The arguments for the main-method

      • oneLineTest

        protected void oneLineTest(java.lang.String command,
               org.hamcrest.Matcher<java.lang.String> expectedOutputMatcher,
               java.lang.String... args0)
        Tests an interactive console program with one command that should output one line. Calls the main method with optional args0 on the test object and runs all commands on it. Asserts that the tested class only called Terminal.printLine once and the output matches the expectedOutputMatcher.
        Parameters:
        command - The command to run on the console.
        expectedOutputMatcher - A Matcher that defines what the test object should print on the console.
        args0 - The arguments for the main-method

      • oneLineTest

        protected void oneLineTest(java.lang.String command,
               java.lang.String expectedOutput,
               java.lang.String... args0)
        Test an interactive console program with one command that should output one line. Calls the main method with optional args0 on the test object and runs all commands on it. Asserts that the tested class called Terminal.printLine only once and the output was exactly expectedOutput.
        Parameters:
        command - The command to run on the console.
        expectedOutput - What the test object should print on the console.
        args0 - The arguments for the main-method

Asserts that the tested class called Terminal.printLine only once and the output matches the expectedOutputMatcher.

      • sessionTest

        protected void sessionTest(Run[] runs,
               java.lang.String... args0)
        Tests an interactive console program with the provided runs, allowing no output before the first run. runs define both the command to be run as well as the expected results.

        This method asserts that no output was made at all before the first run.

        Parameters:
        runs - The runs to run on the interactive console.
        args0 - The arguments for the main-method
        See Also:
        Run

      • sessionTest

        protected void sessionTest(Run initOutputRun,
               Run[] runs,
               java.lang.String... args0)
        Tests an interactive console program with the provided runs, asserting the output before the first run. The runs define both the command to be run as well as the expected results.

        This method asserts that the first output made before the first run fulfils the needs of initOutputRun.

        Parameters:
        initOutputRun - A run specifying the output before the first run of runs is run. The command of this run is irrelevant, it will never be excuted.
        runs - The runs to run on the interactive console.
        args0 - The arguments for the main-method
        See Also:
        Run

      • oneLineTest

        protected void oneLineTest(java.lang.String[] commands,
               java.lang.String expectedOutput,
               java.lang.String... args0)
        Tests an interactive console program with multiple commands that should output one line. Calls the main method with optional args0 on the test object and runs all commands on it. Asserts that the tested class called Terminal.printLine only once and the output was exactly expectedOutput.
        Parameters:
        commands - The commands to run on the test object.
        expectedOutput - What the test object should print on the console.
        args0 - The arguments for the main-method

      • setAllowedSystemExitStatus

        protected final void setAllowedSystemExitStatus(SystemExitStatus status)
        If the tested class is allowed but not required to call System.exit with a certain status, set it through this method. The default status is null, which disables the new system exit status checking in favour of the deprecated way through defaultSystemExitStatus(). The setting stays until the next call to this method.

        NOTE: This setting only takes effect if setExpectedSystemStatus(SystemExitStatus) was called with null!

        Parameters:
        status - The x the tested class may System.exit with. null to disable the new way of system exit status checking.

      • setExpectedSystemStatus

        protected final void setExpectedSystemStatus(SystemExitStatus status)
        If you expect a certain system exit status (which means the tested class has to call System.exit, instead of just being allowed to), set is through this method. The default status is null, which means no restriction on the method's system exit status. The setting stays until the next call to this method.

        NOTE: This setting overrides setAllowedSystemExitStatus(SystemExitStatus): The allowed system exit status is ignored as long as the expected status is not null.

        Parameters:
        status - The x the tested class has to call System.exit with. Set to null if the tested class does not necessary have to call System.exit.

      • wrapInArray

        protected java.lang.String[] wrapInArray(java.lang.String s)
        Parameters:
        s - A String.
        Returns:
        An Array containing s as only element.

      • joinAsIsMatchers

        protected java.util.List<org.hamcrest.Matcher<java.lang.String>> joinAsIsMatchers(java.lang.String[] strings)

      • getDefaultTimeoutMs

        protected int getDefaultTimeoutMs()
        The default timeout for a test. This implementation returns 5000. Override this method to adapt your own timeout!
        Returns:
        5000
